title: A False Alarm in Aachen
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004042520" crop="592" type="image"]

Acting on a tip, German special police officers detained three non-Germans on Tuesday morning as they emerged from a job center in Alsdorf, a suburb of Aachen near the Belgian and Dutch borders, and later detained four more people in the Aachen area in an operation that lasted through the afternoon. 

But by evening, all seven detainees had been released, and the interior minister, Thomas de Maiziere, was telling reporters that none of them “is the man we sought.”

Mr. de Maiziere said the early tip led the police to believe that they might be on the trail of “a big fish,” meaning an important terror suspect on the run, though he did not specify who that was.

The German news media followed the developments closely after the first reports of detentions around lunchtime. 

The size of the police operation and Mr. de Maiziere’s hurried appearance before reporters indicated how nervous the authorities are in Germany, which he said remained a major target for terrorists.

Mr. de Maiziere also suggested that the Syrian passport found at the scene of one of the Paris attacks might be a “false trail” placed deliberately by the Islamic State attackers to turn public opinion against Syrian refugees. He said it would be unusual for a migrant to have registered with three different countries — Greece, Serbia and Croatia — as the person named in the passport appeared to have done.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

But by evening, all seven detainees had been released, and the interior minister, Thomas de Maiziere, was telling reporters that none of them “is the man we sought.”

Mr. de Maiziere said the early tip led the police to believe that they might be on the trail of “a big fish,” meaning an important terror suspect on the run, though he did not specify who that was.

The German news media followed the developments closely after the first reports of detentions around lunchtime.

The size of the police operation and Mr. de Maiziere’s hurried appearance before reporters indicated how nervous the authorities are in Germany, which he said remained a major target for terrorists.

Mr. de Maiziere also suggested that the Syrian passport found at the scene of one of the Paris attacks might be a “false trail” placed deliberately by the Islamic State attackers to turn public opinion against Syrian refugees. He said it would be unusual for a migrant to have registered with three different countries — Greece, Serbia and Croatia — as the person named in the passport appeared to have done.

title: Killed at a Birthday Party
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004041398" crop="190" type="image"]

Guillaume Le Dramp had taken the night off from his job to attend a birthday party at La Belle Équipe bistro. He died along with 18 others there on Friday.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/17/world/europe/waiter-killed-in-paris-attacks-is-remembered-as-a-bon-vivant.html

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Guillaume Le Dramp had taken the night off from his job to attend a birthday party at La Belle Équipe bistro. He died along with 18 others there on Friday.

Waiter Killed in Paris Attacks Is Remembered as a Bon Vivant

By DAN BILEFSKY

Guillaume Le Dramp had taken the night off from his job to attend a birthday party at La Belle Équipe bistro, where he died along with 18 others on Friday.

title: Attorney General Says  Syrian Refugees Will Be Well Vetted
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004042434" crop="592" type="image"]

With Republicans seeking to block Syrian refugees from entering the United States in the wake of the Paris attacks, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch told Congress on Tuesday that she was confident the administration could weed out any security threats through “significant vetting” of the refugees.

The Obama administration’s plan to bring 10,000 refugees into the country next year will pose “challenges,” but there is a “significant and robust” process to identify possible terrorists, Ms. Lynch said at a House Judiciary Committee hearing.

The process includes checking domestic and foreign databases to spot any matches with known terror threats, she said. The administration, she said, “will make every effort to vet every refugee coming into the United States.” 

Robert W. Goodlatte, the Virginia Republican who is chairman of the committee, expressed skepticism, saying at the hearing that the administration’s plan would leave the country vulnerable to a Paris-style attack. 

Mr. Goodlatte cited earlier testimony from James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., concerning the difficulties in using databases to identify threats, because they contain little reliable information from Syria. At least one of the Paris attackers is reported to have entered France from Syria as a refugee.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
With Republicans seeking to block Syrian refugees from entering the United States in the wake of the Paris attacks, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch told Congress on Tuesday that she was confident the administration could weed out any security threats through “significant vetting” of the refugees.

The Obama administration’s plan to bring 10,000 refugees into the country next year will pose “challenges,” but there is a “significant and robust” process to identify possible terrorists, Ms. Lynch said at a House Judiciary Committee hearing.

The process includes checking domestic and foreign databases to spot any matches with known terror threats, she said. The administration, she said, “will make every effort to vet every refugee coming into the United States.”

Robert W. Goodlatte, the Virginia Republican who is chairman of the committee, expressed skepticism, saying at the hearing that the administration’s plan would leave the country vulnerable to a Paris-style attack.

Mr. Goodlatte cited earlier testimony from James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., concerning the difficulties in using databases to identify threats, because they contain little reliable information from Syria. At least one of the Paris attackers is reported to have entered France from Syria as a refugee.

title: Hollande to Visit Washington and Moscow Next Week
content:
President François Hollande of France will visit Washington and Moscow next week to discuss the fight against the Islamic State face to face with President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia,  the French government announced.

A statement from the Élysée  Palace said that Mr. Hollande would  arrive in Washington next Tuesday and then travel to Moscow two days later. 

Referring to the militant group by its Arabic acronym, the statement said the visits would be part of the "international community's action in the fight against Daesh and the resolution of the situation in Syria."

Secretary of State John Kerry had announced the Washington visit earlier. 

Mr. Obama and Mr. Hollande were supposed to meet at the G-20 summit at Antalya, Turkey, on Sunday, but after the Paris attacks Friday night, Mr. Hollande decided to stay in France. He sent his foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, to Turkey to meet with Mr. Obama and other foreign leaders instead.

Before leaving Turkey bound for the Philippines, Mr. Obama called the Paris attacks "heinous" and said that many flags across the United States were "at half-staff in solidarity with our French allies."

Mr. Obama said that the United States and France were already streamlining military cooperation and intelligence-sharing in the wake of the attacks.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
President François Hollande of France will visit Washington and Moscow next week to discuss the fight against the Islamic State face to face with President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the French government announced.

A statement from the Élysée Palace said that Mr. Hollande would arrive in Washington next Tuesday and then travel to Moscow two days later.

Referring to the militant group by its Arabic acronym, the statement said the visits would be part of the “international community’s action in the fight against Daesh and the resolution of the situation in Syria.”

Secretary of State John Kerry had announced the Washington visit earlier.

Mr. Obama and Mr. Hollande were supposed to meet at the G-20 summit at Antalya, Turkey, on Sunday, but after the Paris attacks Friday night, Mr. Hollande decided to stay in France. He sent his foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, to Turkey to meet with Mr. Obama and other foreign leaders instead.

Before leaving Turkey bound for the Philippines, Mr. Obama called the Paris attacks “heinous” and said that many flags across the United States were “at half-staff in solidarity with our French allies.”

Mr. Obama said that the United States and France were already streamlining military cooperation and intelligence-sharing in the wake of the attacks.

title: A Rallying Cry in Paris: ‘Everyone To the Bar!’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004042385" crop="592" type="image"]

Parisian restaurant owners are calling for a very French act of defiance. Tous au bistrot — “Everyone to the bar!” — invites people to gather in local bars and cafes and observe a minute of silence tonight at 9.

[nytmedia id="100000004042312" crop="190" type="image"]

“It’s about going to your local bistro, to go out again, go to a place where you can have a beer, some peanuts, a plate of sausages, anything,” said Alexandre Cammas, founder of Le Fooding, a French food magazine that created a logo for the occasion and is helping the restaurant owners get the word out.

Restaurant owners, cooks and customers have voiced support online, using the hashtags #TousAuBistrot and #JeSuisEnTerrasse — “I am on the terrace,” a reference to the sidewalk tables and outdoor seating common in Paris. Photographs of people raising their glasses have already begun circulating online.

https://twitter.com/lgauriat/status/666588706078367744

Jean Jullien’s drawing of the Eiffel Tower, which has become a symbol of global solidarity with France since the attacks, is turned into a plate with a fork and knife beside it, a reminder of the joie de vivre that the terrorists took aim at on Friday night. “It will be an act of peaceful resistance,” Mr. Cammas said.

“What makes Paris has been attacked and hurt,” he said. “It is very important that Paris gets up again, fast, and continues to be Paris. Otherwise, it would mean that we let them win.”

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

Restaurant owners, cooks and customers have voiced support online, using the hashtags #TousAuBistrot and #JeSuisEnTerrasse — “I am on the terrace,” a reference to the sidewalk tables and outdoor seating common in Paris. Photographs of people raising their glasses have already begun circulating online.

.@bleugardlozere : nous trinquons à la vie. #tousaubistrot #JeSuisEnTerrasse #Nîmes pic.twitter.com/jOirBR3eme

— Laurent Gauriat (@lgauriat) November 17, 2015

Jean Jullien’s drawing of the Eiffel Tower, which has become a symbol of global solidarity with France since the attacks, is turned into a plate with a fork and knife beside it, a reminder of the joie de vivre that the terrorists took aim at on Friday night. “It will be an act of peaceful resistance,” Mr. Cammas said.

“What makes Paris has been attacked and hurt,” he said. “It is very important that Paris gets up again, fast, and continues to be Paris. Otherwise, it would mean that we let them win.”

title: What Travelers Can Expect in Paris Now
content: Whether for business or pleasure, Paris is one of the most visited cities in the world, but travelers arriving now, in the wake of the attacks, are likely to encounter some complications to their plans. The New York Times travel desk has compiled a guide with updated information about flights, hotels, getting around and what tourists can do to help.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

The New York Times travel desk has compiled a guide with updated information about flights, hotels, getting around and what tourists can do to help.

title: Anger Over Daily Mail Cartoon Equating Refugees to Rats
content: An editorial cartoon published on Tuesday by The Daily Mail, which seems to equate migrants and refugees fleeing wars in the Middle East with rats, prompted a wave of outrage across social media. The charged image, which features caricatures of bearded Muslim men with exaggerated noses and veiled women crossing "Europe's open borders," along with scurrying rats, was drawn by the cartoonist Stan McMurtry, who uses the pen name Mac. https://twitter.com/thekarami/status/666616138323783680 The outline of a rifle can be seen on the back of one of the men crossing the border, a clear reference to the fact that one of the suspected attackers in Paris entered the European Union through Greece, and registered as an asylum seeker using what might have been a forged Syrian passport. (Police sources in Serbia told The Guardian that at least two men entered that country this year using passports with details identical to the one found near the body of one of the attackers in Paris.) A satirical Twitter account critical of the British tabloid, @DMReporter, captioned the image, "Our resident cartoonist Mac confuses casting a satirical eye over the day's events with overt casual racism." The cartoon was widely denounced as racist and the image reminded many observers of Nazi propaganda. https://twitter.com/digitonal/status/666567997448916993 https://twitter.com/katesang/status/666585691296542720 https://twitter.com/goldipipschmidt/status/666597483397693440 https://twitter.com/iainaitch/status/666574487530377216 Pete Fraser, a musician from London who lives in Stockholm, did a quick Google image search and discovered that the Mail's cartoon bore a resemblance to the final image from an anti-Semitic children’s book published in 1936 by Julius Streicher’s Stürmer publishing house, "Trust No Fox in the Green Meadow and No Jew on his Oath." https://twitter.com/petefrasermusic/status/666585744232812544 That children's book, drawn by Elvira Bauer, ends with the image of young Germans celebrating the hoped-for expulsion of the Jews back to "the country/ Which cradled Jewish ancestry," in the "far-off south."

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
An editorial cartoon published on Tuesday by The Daily Mail, which seems to equate migrants and refugees fleeing wars in the Middle East with rats, prompted a wave of outrage across social media.

The charged image, which features caricatures of bearded Muslim men with exaggerated noses and veiled women crossing “Europe’s open borders,” along with scurrying rats, was drawn by the cartoonist Stan McMurtry, who uses the pen name Mac.

Comparing a religious minority in Europe to rats because that's how Daily Mail does it. pic.twitter.com/6Zg23IlmJA

— Arash Karami (@thekarami) November 17, 2015

The outline of a rifle can be seen on the back of one of the men crossing the border, a clear reference to the fact that one of the suspected attackers in Paris entered the European Union through Greece, and registered as an asylum seeker using what might have been a forged Syrian passport. (Police sources in Serbia told The Guardian that at least two men entered that country this year using passports with details identical to the one found near the body of one of the attackers in Paris.)

A satirical Twitter account critical of the British tabloid, @DMReporter, captioned the image, “Our resident cartoonist Mac confuses casting a satirical eye over the day’s events with overt casual racism.”

The cartoon was widely denounced as racist and the image reminded many observers of Nazi propaganda.

Not going to link to it, but the Daily Mail's 'Mac' cartoon today is the most disgusting thing I think I have ever seen in the British press

— Andy Digitonal (@digitonal) November 17, 2015

I'm not inclined to share it, but the Daily Mail cartoon today could be lifted from the 1930's.

— Kate Sang (@katesang) November 17, 2015

Mac's cartoon in today's Daily Mail is vile, racist and anti-Muslim. Horribly similar to Nazi anti-Semitic propaganda.

— Pippa Goldschmidt (@goldipipschmidt) November 17, 2015

One assumes the estate of Goebbels will be having a word with the Mail about today’s Mac cartoon.

— Iain Aitch (@iainaitch) November 17, 2015

Pete Fraser, a musician from London who lives in Stockholm, did a quick Google image search and discovered that the Mail’s cartoon bore a resemblance to the final image from an anti-Semitic children’s book published in 1936 by Julius Streicher’s Stürmer publishing house, “Trust No Fox in the Green Meadow and No Jew on his Oath.”

One of these was in today's Daily Mail and one is nazi propaganda. Take your time. pic.twitter.com/VjPYrwYKvS

— Pete Fraser (@petefrasermusic) November 17, 2015

That children’s book, drawn by Elvira Bauer, ends with the image of young Germans celebrating the hoped-for expulsion of the Jews back to “the country/ Which cradled Jewish ancestry,” in the “far-off south.”

title: Victim’s Husband Tells Terrorists, ‘I Will Not Give You the Gift of Hate’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004042295" crop="480" type="image"]

Antoine Leiris, whose wife was killed when gun-wielding militants invaded a crowded concert hall in Paris, has this message for the killers: “I will not give you the gift of hate.”

Mr. Leiris, a journalist for France Bleu, a network of local and regional radio stations, met his wife, Hélène Muyal-Leiris, 12 years ago, and has been left to raise their toddler son, Melvil, on his own. 

Of the 129 people killed during the attacks on Friday, 89 died at the Bataclan concert hall, where Ms. Muyal-Leiris had been attending a rock concert.

In a moving tribute on Facebook, that had been viewed more than 90,000 times by Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Leiris said he would not allow his grief to turn into hatred. 

Addressing the attackers, he wrote: "You won’t have my hate. On Friday night you took the life of someone exceptional, the love of my life, the mother of my son, but I will not hate you. I do not know who you are and I do not want to know. You are dead inside. If the God for whom you blindly kill really made us in his image, then each bullet in my wife's body is a wound to his heart.”

He went on: “So I will not give you the gift of hate. Even though it is what you were hoping for, responding to hatred with anger would be to fall to the same ignorance that made you the people that you are. You want me to be scared, to distrust my fellow citizens, and to sacrifice my liberty for security. I will play on.”

Mr. Leiris said he had seen his wife the morning of the attacks. “She was as beautiful as she was when she left on Friday night, as beautiful as when I fell forever in love with her more than 12 years ago,” he wrote.

“Of course I am devastated by grief,  I will concede you that small victory, but that will not last long. I know that she will watch over us always and that, one day, we will meet again in that paradise of free souls where you will never be admitted.”

He ended on a note of optimism. “Now it’s just the two of us, my son and I, but we are stronger than all the armies of the world. In fact, I do not have any more time to waste on you, I need to go and get Melvil, who is waking up from his nap. He is only 17 months old, he will eat his afternoon tea as always and then we will go and play as always, and this little boy's entire life will be an affront to you by being happy and free. For he will not hate you either.”

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

I do not know who you are and I do not want to know. You are dead inside. If the God for whom you blindly kill really made us in his image, then each bullet in my wife’s body is a wound to his heart.”

He went on: “So I will not give you the gift of hate. “Of course I am devastated by grief, I will concede you that small victory, but that will not last long. I know that she will watch over us always and that, one day, we will meet again in that paradise of free souls where you will never be admitted.”

He ended on a note of optimism. “Now it’s just the two of us, my son and I, but we are stronger than all the armies of the world. He is only 17 months old, he will eat his afternoon tea as always and then we will go and play as always, and this little boy’s entire life will be an affront to you by being happy and free. For he will not hate you either.”

title: Charlie Hebdo and Other French Publications Deliver Messages of Defiance
content: [nytmedia id="100000004041970" crop="480" type="image"] Like their daily newspaper counterparts, French weeklies and magazines are dedicating their covers to the Paris attacks. On Tuesday, the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, itself the target of a terrorist attack in January, revealed the cover of its latest issue, which will be on newsstands Wednesday. In the magazine’s defiant style, the cover features a bullet-riddled man, spouting champagne, under a headline that reads: “They have weapons. Screw them, we have champagne!” The cover of the culture magazine Les Inrockuptibles offers a message of unity. “In the face of terror, Paris belongs to us,” reads a headline. [nytmedia id="100000004041959" crop="480" type="image"] The magazine had a direct connection to Friday's attacks. Guillaume B. Decherf, a reporter who wrote about rock and metal music, was one of the victims at the Bataclan concert hall. [nytmedia id="100000004041963" crop="480" type="image"] Télérama, a culture and entertainment magazine, offers a similar sentiment on its cover, in a brief but powerful headline: “Life belongs to us.” [nytmedia id="100000004041955" crop="480" type="image"] And Le Nouvel Observateur, a weekly news magazine, put out a special edition on Monday, its typeface in the colors of the French flag.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Like their daily newspaper counterparts, French weeklies and magazines are dedicating their covers to the Paris attacks.

On Tuesday, the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, itself the target of a terrorist attack in January, revealed the cover of its latest issue, which will be on newsstands Wednesday.

In the magazine’s defiant style, the cover features a bullet-riddled man, spouting champagne, under a headline that reads: “They have weapons. Screw them, we have champagne!”

The cover of the culture magazine Les Inrockuptibles offers a message of unity. “In the face of terror, Paris belongs to us,” reads a headline.

The magazine had a direct connection to Friday’s attacks. Guillaume B. Decherf, a reporter who wrote about rock and metal music, was one of the victims at the Bataclan concert hall.

Télérama, a culture and entertainment magazine, offers a similar sentiment on its cover, in a brief but powerful headline: “Life belongs to us.”

And Le Nouvel Observateur, a weekly news magazine, put out a special edition on Monday, its typeface in the colors of the French flag.

title: Eiffel Tower Is Closed Once Again
content:
The Eiffel Tower was closed on Tuesday because of staff members' concerns over safety in the esplanade of the monument, the company that manages the Eiffel Tower said in a statement sent to Agence France-Presse.

A worker told the news agency that the employees wanted to set up barriers to screen visitors before giving them access to the esplanade. Management and employees were scheduled to work out additional security measures at a meeting on Tuesday afternoon, another worker said in a phone interview.

Officials said the tower was scheduled to reopen at 6 p.m.

The monument was closed after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday night. It reopened on Monday, and that evening it was covered with blue, white and red lights — the colors of France's flag — as a tribute to the victims.
